column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/made-himself-a-dominant-edge-player/|“Made Himself A Dominant Edge Player”|The greatness of new Bucs edge rusher Haason Reddick is not overlooked by one iconic Buccaneer. After all
column2: Reddick landed in a mess out of college
column3: one that took years to correct. Drafted by Arizona in 2017
column5: Reddick had three head coaches and three defensive coordinators in his first three seasons. And they all put him at inside linebacker. How many players emerge with multiple Pro Bowls after that? That’s not lost on Hall of Fame Bucs cornerback Rondé Barber
column6: who told the No Off Days podcast that he loves the Reddick signing for Tampa Bay. “I love the way that he plays. I love how he’s overcome his own adversity
column8: they didn’t even know where to play him. If you remember
column10: when Bruce Arians drafted him and didn’t know where to play him — stand-up or inside linebacker. But he kind of redefined himself and made himself a dominant edge player and it’s clearly one of our weaknesses.” The “redefined himself” impresses Joe a ton. Reddick balled out as an edge rusher in 2020 and left in free agency to Carolina. He crushed it there
column12: and then was dominant in Philadelphia. Has there ever been a double-digit sacker with four different teams? Joe can’t think of one. But that Bucs sure hope/expect that’s Reddick. |2025-03-16 19:26:00|231|18|7|Haason Reddick|Overcame adversity|5|Mixed sentiments towards player acquisitions and analysis despite potential upside noted by some fans.|"{""commenter0"": {""username"": ""Pickgrin""

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/talent-upgrade-in-charlie-heck/|Talent Upgrade In Charlie Heck|Former Bucs reserve offensive tackle Justin Skule was on the street for weeks before the Bucs put him on their practice squad in 2022. The 2019 sixth-round pick of the 49ers looked to be done after tearing his ACL before the 2021 season. But
column3: Buccaneers Ring of Honor general manager Jason Licht had a sharp eye for O-line potential and made Skule a rehab project
column4: and he delivered well last season at left and right tackle after a brutal first game filling in for Luke Goedeke. Now Skule is in Minnesota and some Bucs fans are nervous. Change is always unsettling
column5: but the Bucs did get bigger
column9: more talented at the position by signing free agent Charlie Heck this week. Heck measured a whisker under 6-8 at the NFL Scouting Combine in 2020
column10: and he was 311 pounds with a 28-inch vertical leap. He was a very big man running a 5.16 40-yard dash. Drafted by the Texans in Round 4
column11: Heck was well known in Houston for remaking his body. He transformed into a much leaner 308 pounds and was the Texans’ starting right tackle in 2021. A year later
column12: Heck lost his starting gig under a new coaching staff (Lovie Smith) and then stuck around for another Texans coaching staff in 2023 before playing for the Cardinals and 49ers last season. Simply put
column15: has a lot more experience (23 starts) than Skule and seems to be more talented. Heck is the son of Chiefs offensive line coach and 12-year NFL lineman Andy Heck
column16: so he’s got a pedigree. And Joe wonders what Charlie Heck could achieve in Tampa with what might be the best O-line coaches he’s been around and the best linemen he’s worked alongside. The Bucs coached up Skule
column17: and they might coach up Heck to his likely untouched ceiling. Ira Kaufman Talks Bucs Drafting A Cornerback

column131: ""post"": ""Heck may be a quick replacement/minor upgrade over Skule and kudos to Licht and Co. on this signing but the Bucs also have a hole at back-up center.  There are a couple thirty something vets who have always lacked power available in FA and a handful of projects available later in the draft so this has the potential to be a problem if Barton gets hurt.  It is proper that Hainsey moved on to somewhere where he can earn a starting position but as far as I can see recently released Patriot David Andrews is the best option.  He is only 6\u20192\u2033/300 and is coming off shoulder surgery so one of the lackluster centers in the draft may be the best way to go.  That is what the Pats seem to be doing.  Andrews started nearly every game for most of a decade there after coming in as a UDFA and being pressed into starting week one.  He\u2019d be an asset as a mentor to Barton even if he never sees the field.  He is old
column132: small and broken but seems to be the best available to fill that roster hole unless Licht and Co. can find a small school gem in the draft or swing a trade.""

column6: he deserves a lot of credit

column9: which leads us to high levels of execution. I love seeing quarterbacks that are in charge of recognizing the blitz
column10: getting their teams in good play selection.” Yeah

https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/major-respect-for-joe-tryon-shoyinka/|Major Respect For Joe Tryon-Shoyinka|After only 16 sacks in his 72 Bucs games
column2: struggling edge rusher Joe Tryon-Shoyinka has left the building. Few Tampa Bay fans will miss him
column3: but Tryon-Shoyinka moved on in a professional manner and commands respect. That was the word from his former Bucs position coach
column4: Larry Foote. Joe asked Foote for a final thought on Tampa Bay’s 2021 first-round pick
column5: who will earn $4.75 million next season with the Browns. “It was good. I don’t know if he reached his expectations that
column7: he wanted. But he did a lot of good ball for us
column8: ” Foote said. “Hope for the best for him up in Cleveland. Gonna be a big adjustment weatherwise. But Joe is a great guy. Even when he was being demoted
column9: he kept the same attitude and juice. I really respect that about him.” Great to hear Tryon-Shoyinka was a class act as the Bucs cut his playing time last season. Joe has read many reports of the Tryon-Shoyinka signing from Cleveland and it seems he’s eager to get in a more attack-minded front with Browns defensive coordinator Jim Schwartz. Photos of JTS hugging it up with Myles Garrett made Joe chuckle. Joe will be paying attention to see if JTS is a different player (better or worse) at his new stop. Ira Kaufman Talks Bucs Drafting A Cornerback

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/jihaad-campbell-and-the-bucs/|Jihaad Campbell And The Bucs|Joe often likes to say that what a team does in free agency is a window into its upcoming draft. Fans know what holes there are on the Bucs roster before the combine when (coughcough) illegal tampering kicks off (coughcough). So the holes remaining after free agency are likely the draft targets. Despite Lavonte David coming back at inside linebacker
column2: the position is still a major need
column3: maybe more so than cornerback. The Bucs really pumped up SirVocea Dennis at the combine and Joe agrees he has untapped potential. Bucs coach Todd Bowles even said when Dennis got hurt and was lost for the season with a bum shoulder
column4: his absence hurt the defense. Given how terrible the pass defense was
column5: specifically in the middle of the field
column6: Joe believes Bowles. For all the talent Dennis flashes
column8: he cannot stay on the field. For all we know
column9: Dennis could be the next Derrick Brooks but if he’s in the tub it doesn’t matter. So will the Bucs really bank on an injury-prone inside linebacker when it appears this team has a real shot to make a Super Bowl run? Throw in that David is very likely entering his final season
column10: and one can see how badly the Bucs need an inside linebacker. Joe has been really
column11: really high on this Jihaad Campbell out of Alabama. He could be the linebacker that the Bucs thought Devin White would/should have been. And since off-ball linebackers like Campbell don’t normally go high in the draft
column12: there’s a shot he could be there at No. 19. Jordan Reid of BSPN is high on Campbell
column13: too. But based on free agency
column14: Reid isn’t sure Campbell will be on the board when the Bucs pick at No. 19. The way off-ball linebackers got paid in free agency tells him teams have a higher value on that position this year. Off-ball linebackers have surprisingly become hot commodities in free agency. Both teams that were just in the Super Bowl paid hefty prices to keep the centerpieces of their defenses in place
column15: as Zack Baun returned to the Eagles on a three-year
column16: $51 million deal while the Chiefs brought back Nick Bolton on a three-year
column17: $45 million contract. The Jets also re-signed Jamien Sherwood before free agency after his big season. With the growing emphasis on the running game
column18: teams showed they would spend on the position this offseason. None of those three backers Reid cited were first-round picks. Bolton was picked in the second round
column19: Baun in the third and Sherwood in the fifth. While Reid isn’t sure that Campbell will be available at No. 19
column20: Reid seems pretty certain Campbell will land in the NFC South. And if he’s there at No. 19
column21: you can go ahead and print up a Bucs No. 11 jersey for him (sorry Michael Pratt). Campbell is my No. 14 player in this class and the prototype at the position. He could be drafted as high as No. 8 (Panthers)
column22: and his floor is likely No. 19 (Buccaneers). The Falcons at No. 15 make a lot of sense as a landing spot
column23: as they need linebackers and players capable of rushing the quarterback. Drafting Campbell just may make this Bucs defense complete. Haason Reddick will ignite a dormant pass rush
column24: Joe believes. And Campbell next to David seems frightening (in a good way). The only element left is a quality backup corner because there are three sure things in life: death
column25: taxes and Jamel Dean being unable to finish a playoff game. Man
column26: Joe sure hopes Dean can find a magic elixir to stay healthy. Ira Kaufman Talks Bucs Drafting A Cornerback

column451: ""post"": ""I can\u2019t go for any inside linebacker in the first round.  Ever.  It\u2019s tempting to rate a team\u2019s needs and address the highest need in the first round
column452: second highest need in the second
column453: third in the third then go BPA through to the end but that is fan logic.  After pass rush
column454: ILB and CB the Bucs can be said to need more picks in this draft.  The talent at the first round of this draft is mostly back half of the second/top of the third in most other drafts.  It\u2019s almost always a good idea to trade back out of the first but never more than it is this year.  Normally I\u2019d be upset with the Bucs parting with their first round pick but for every position available at 19 there are nearly equal options from picks 50-100 and beyond.  The Bucs don\u2019t have many picks this year and the second through fourth rounds are chock full of capable starters.  Teddye Buchanan from Cal is an instinctive
column455: ball-hawking natural blitzer who is a little undersized so he\u2019ll be there in the fifth round.  The top ten ILBs in the league last year were all playing at 225-230 lbs except for one who played at 245.  This defense needs to play the pass better.  Emmanwori and Buchanan are who I would target.  Tykee Smith takes too many bad angles and fails as a tackler too often to be the safety he wants to be in 2025.  Malaki Starks would be my next choice if Emmanwori is gone by 19 not because the Bucs need a safety more than any other position but because that is where value and opportunity to meet a need converge for this pick in this draft.""

column2: Larry Foote Demonstrate Why Football Is About Relationships|Joe has heard this cliché many times and Joe used to think it only applied to coaching. And yeah
column3: maybe it does apply to coaching. But it seems
column4: at least for new Bucs edge rusher Haason Reddick
column5: his relationship with Bucs outside linebackers coach Larry Foote was a key reason why Reddick chose Tampa Bay. Football is about relationships. Reddick and Foote first crossed paths in Arizona. They reunite in Tampa Bay. When Reddick was a first-round pick of Arizona in 2017
column6: Foote was the Cardinals’ inside linebackers coach. And right away
column7: to hear Foote talk on Friday
column8: the Cardinals made a mistake with Reddick. The rookie edge rusher was moved to inside linebacker
column9: a position he had never played. Joe asked Foote about this Friday and Foote said someone higher up the food chain than him saw Reddick “was a freak” playing off-the-ball linebacker during Senior Bowl practices. The Cardinals thought they had a monster on their hands and moved Reddick inside. “It’s a big factor
column12: just how he helped me grow as a player
column13: as a young player out in Arizona
column14: ” Reddick said of his reunion with Foote. “You know
column16: the attention that he took to make sure — he understood my situation
column17: right? A kid coming into the league who’s never played inside linebacker before
column18: somebody who was able to do it the way he did it in his career
column21: everything that he gave me. A lot of that stuff stuck with me and allowed me to continue to grow as a player moving forward. “So to reconnect with him
column22: maybe it will be me teaching him some things this time around — nah! (Laughs)” After Reddick went to the Eagles — by that time Foote was coaching in Tampa — whenever the Eagles and Bucs played
column23: Foote found Reddick and made sure everything was good with him personally and professionally. Those gestures deepened Reddick’s appreciation. “It’s great to be back around with [Foote]
column24: ” Reddick said. “I’ve always loved his energy
column25: even when we got to play against him. No matter where he was coaching
column26: he always had the time and was excited to see me. “[Foote] made sure they we would talk. He’d ask me about my family
column27: things [like] that. We always kept the connection. So it is great to be back [with Foote].” So football is sometimes about relationships with players. When the Bucs were trying to recruit Reddick
column28: the Bucs already had a built-in advantage. A relationship advantage.|2025-03-16 08:00:00|428|12|6|Haason Reddick|Football relationships key in player-coach connections and team recruitment.|8|Overall positive sentiment with emphasis on relationships
column30: and faith in the team.|"{""commenter0"": {""username"": ""Lt. Dan""

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/tristan-wirfs-knows-how-to-make-hot-women-feel-old/|Tristan Wirfs Knows How To Make Women Feel Old|Bucs left tackle Tristan Wirfs may have a future in comedy if he plans to work after his football days are done. Last week Wirfs sat down for a “live” podcast at a Bucs event at The Licht House called “She is Football
column2: ” a two-day celebration of women and football. FOX Sports personalities/sideline reporters Erin Andrews and Charissa Thompson were part of the festivities and recorded their podcast “Calm Down.” Wirfs was a special guest and at one point was referred to by Andrews as “cutie pie.” (Strangely
column3: Thompson referenced a bachelor party she attended the previous evening. Not bachelorette. “Bachelor.”) There
column4: Wirfs decided to tread upon a subject women over 40 detest: calendars. Andrews and Thompson are in that group. So the subject of being a rookie drafted to keep Tom Brady on his two feet came up. Wirfs explained the pressure that was on him. “[The Bucs are] like
column8: I’ll try my best. He’s fragile
column9: he’s old.'” This sparked gasps and laughs from the crowd of (mostly?) women. The nerve of Wirfs to refer to then-43-year-old Brady as “old!” Wirfs immediately realized the audience and then held out his palm and said
column11: not that old. Not that old
column12: ladies. Not that old.” The remark got a reaction from Andrews
column14: “Tristan! He’s a year older than me. Calm down!” To which Wirfs responded
column15: “He’s like two years younger than my mom.” Rim shot! Careful there
column16: Tristan. Comedy like that may get you in hot water in the future. Don’t want to alienate half your potential market — if you don’t sit back and enjoy the good life after you retire from football. Also interesting
column17: since this was recorded a week ago
